content.description: The natural warmup boulder traverse a foot above ground level, on the vertical face between Arena Arete and Chossy's Corner. It's on par with, or a hair harder than, Arena Arete. Move delicately between little flakes at various heights and angles, a good drill for face climbing.
content.protection: None needed, right off very level ground.
content.location: Right side of Alapocas Main Wall at ground level. The only vertical, consistent section of wall there.

content.description: #12 on Hartmans online Alapocus guide.  Just to the left of Chossy's Corner.  A stretch of almost non-existing crimps in all the wrong angles makes this a difficult short climb.
content.protection: Use top rope anchors at the top of Grey Streak.  To reach the anchor make the easy scramble up the slab to the ledge, or if you are not comfortable doing so, top rope or rap from the anchors at the very top of Chipper or Spankey

content.description:
Climb the A-shaped face to the right of the obvious crack. Avoid the crack on the left, otherwise you'll be on Hungry for Me (5.5). There is a very easy pinch at the top of the A. Use this to "top out".

 Wasn't sure what to grade this as it's technical for the area but super secure. Could be anywhere from 5.6 to 5.8 depending on who you ask.
content.protection: Bolts for toprope anchors with rap rings.
content.location: This route is located to the left of the main wall. It is below two bolts that can be accessed about halfway up the walk around to the top. The climb is to the right of Hungry for Me and avoids the main crack.

content.description: Tallest stretch of vertical rock at Alapocus.  Crux is in the middle traversing from right to left before ascending to the top.  From the bottom you can work your way up the sloping ledge or try to scale straight up using the holds on the bore-hole.   Once on the right ledge it's a precarious balancing act and doing the splits to reach the left side and palm the minimal slopers to work your way left.
content.location: Base is located on the ledge to the right of the rock face.  Can start using top rope from the bottom using Temptation or Chossy's Corner, or just scale the easy sloper to the top of the wide open ledge.  If your not comfortable getting up to the ledge and can't throw the top rope over the ledge, rappel down.

content.description: Named for the "cannon ball blast" that this route climbs through. Tough feet at the beginning (after easy slab) with a powerful crux for the grade.
content.protection: Bolts w/ rap rings at top, a cam in the .75-2 range may be helpful as a directional
content.location: Left side of main wall left.

content.description: A former sport climb (rest in peace, homie). A short, crimpy, technical slab. Follow the two chopped bolts in the "groove" between two inward facing cuts in the rock. Balancey moves to a short crimpy crux followed by three possible finishes and counting... a dyno (most common way), some delicate foot moves and some features out to the left, and the static direct way with layback moves on bad crimps and bad feet. All three feel about the same difficulty to me but I'm 6ft so ymmv. More opinions on grade needed, I included the grade from the guide
content.protection: A few crash pads if you're feeling good about the high crux. A static line on the iron eyelet at the top is necessary if you want to keep a toprope in good shape. If you feel weird about using just the eyelet, you could maybe place a number 2 in the blast hole to climbers left of it
content.location: On the near-vertical face on the far right of the main wall along a clear, previously bolted line.

content.description:
Start on the middle ledge of the Main Wall, below the highly visible diagonal crack leading into the left corner of the roof block. Tiptoe up the starting slab, minding the lack of friction on the painted-over spraypaint - or bypassing it on either side. Go straight for the crack, or traverse up and right under the roof and back left from there. Wriggle and writhe through the roof notch and you're done. 

  The most dramatic established line at Alapocas.
content.protection: No pro, toprope only. A pair of good bolts is at the top or the wall above the route. A friendly cliffside tree can be slung for safety while setting the anchor.
content.location: In the middle of the main wall, starting on the ledge two thirds of the way up the face.

content.protection: Top rope (2 bolt anchor). Can be led with standard rack of small cams. Pink-red tricam placements galore. Couldn’t find any good nut placements.
content.location: To left of Old Granddad, just right of corner, slightly shorter easy slab. #6 in Hartman's guide.

content.description: fun low angle, super easy climb
content.location: #7 in Hartman's guide, obvious longest low angle slab on the Main Wall

content.description: I'm sure it's been done before by bored folks like me, but I figured it deserves a name and a place on here because it's fun and alapocas needs more routes! One could argue it's just Hungry for Me with bad beta, but that would make the route sad so don't say that
content.protection: Bolts w/ rap rings at top
content.location: Basically use the hand-crack of "hungry for me" for your feet until you can't anymore. Then shoot up directly from there. Try not to linger onto hungry for me because the routes don't really intersect.

content.description: An easy low angle slab climb. Good footwork practice.
content.location: first obvious slab from the left

content.description: Find the anchor under a tree along the dirt path from the paved trail to the cliff top. Climb the path of least resistance up the low angled face to the anchor, bearing right when needed. A major diagonal crack is the main feature, partially filled with old tree roots. Ledges and other features offer plenty to work with for a beginning climber.
content.protection:
Two bolt anchor. 

  I looked really hard for trad pro to practice when I was there, but there's little or nothing. You're really just bouldering if you're not on toprope on this little guy.
content.location: Main Wall Left: the sole route on the left side of the Main Wall.

content.description: Excellent tiny feet and almost impossible hands make this a really fun climb / boulder problem... for delaware...
content.protection: Boulder or top rope, no great anchor for this spot without lots of rope wear...
content.location: Start directly at the base where the grey corner meets the red rock, a reachy move to a nice thin hold halfway up will be very difficult for the vertically challenged.

content.description: climb the obvious seam in the dihedral, left side of which is vertical, right side is super easy slab
The route's dichotomy is between the slabby footwork of the lower half, and the vertical handwork of the upper half (where the crux can be found).
content.protection: A pair of bolts makes setting a toprope fairly simple.
content.location:
The route starts on a ledge halfway up the left side of the main wall. A use trail follows the creek left of the wall uphill past a pool and small waterfalls. From the top, one can reach the anchor bolts, and rappel down to the start of the climb. 

  Alternately, one can scramble from the ground up a series of slabs and ledges, which can be seasonally overgrown or dirty.

content.description: Climb the short, chossy, far right bottom corner of the Alapocas main wall. The crux is the final move.
content.protection: A pair of eyebolts were drilled on top of this route in spring 2010.
content.location: The ledge where a toprope anchor is set can be scrambled up from the left corner fairly easily. One can do a very short rappel off the anchor bolts if not comfortable downclimbing it.

content.description:
#10 in Hartmans online Alapocus guide.  Can set top rope anchor from the anchors for Chipper or Spanky, but may need to use a directional off the large iron eyelet.  Alternately, scramble up the slab to the top of the ledge and set an anchor directly in the iron eyelet and use a directional from the Rambo anchors.

 This route may not be tall, but it makes up for it in quality and variety.  Some classic arete side pull moves at the cart, food placement just where you need them, and sweet easy dyno (or reach if your tall) to get to the top ledge and pull up.  Although not terribly difficult, might be the funnest route at Alapocus.
content.protection: Top Rope from Iron eyelet.  Good idea to bring a rope protector or use a stick link to prevent rope drag over the ledge.

content.description: Enter a description of this area.
